text: Nevertheless, the world’s dry regions are probably the least familiar land areas on Earth outside the polar realm.
For many visitors, desert scenery exhibits a striking beauty; to others, the terrain seems bleak.
At some places the rocks are tinted orange and red.
The word desert literally means “deserted” or “unoccupied.
Desert landscapes and their development provide another excellent example of the strong link between climate and geology.
However, the concept of dryness is a relative one that refers to any situation in which an ongoing water deficiency exists.
Their profiles are not softened by a continuous carpet of soil and abundant plant life.
For many dry regions this is an appropriate description, although where water is available in deserts, plants and animals thrive.
Rather, the effects of tectonic forces, running water, and wind are all apparent.
No matter which feeling is elicited, it is clear that deserts are very different from the more humid places where most people live.
As you will see, arid regions are not dominated by a single geologic process.
Instead, barren rocky outcrops with steep, angular slopes are common.

That is, how much rain defines the boundary between humid and dry regions?
We all recognize that deserts are dry places, but just what is meant by the term dry?
